Slow Factory

 /
Open Education

Open Education Initiatives for Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic communities taught by Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic scholars, thinkers and educators

In April 2020, Slow Factory hosted a 4-part “crash course” in Sustainability Literacy. We annouced on a Monday, and on Friday 1,500 people tuned in, engaged and learned about sustainability at the intersection of environmental and social justice.

Course Preview:

Global Audience:

You can help us continue this work!

We are fundraising to allow us to run community-centric Open Education programs taught in collaboration with Teju Adisa-Farar, Maytha Alhassen, Hawa Arsala, Aja Barber, Tahirah Hairston, Sophia Li, Korina Emmerich, Nicole Mclaughlin, Ibada Wadud, Céline Semaan and the Slow Factory team of experts. This initiative is part of our core mission at Slow Factory Foundation.

Brands: Show Solidarity


Citizens: make a monthly donation to support this important work:

Launching to the public in September 2020 — the fund will be supporting the instructors to build and teach the curriculum to participants.

Sustainability Literacy: Exploring solutions around Race, Equity and Climate Positive frameworks

Skill training curriculum will include:

  • Journalism
  • Food
  • Agriculture
  • Fashion design
  • Modeling
  • Sourcing & Manufacturing
  • Design
  • Jewelry Design




Brands: Do the Work

Support education; it’s the backbone of progress

Contributions of $5000 and over will be recognized with public thanks during the programs.

Support Peer-to-Peer Education

Good for the Earth,
Good for the People

Slow Factory Foundation is dedicated to improving sustainability literacy in fashion.

Using a holistic, human-centered approach, we bridge science, human rights, technology, fashion & culture to develop products, resources and certifications for industry and consumers alike.
